verb.description: Put (things) in a neat, attractive, or required order.
examples: she had just finished arranging the flowers
the columns are arranged in 12 rows

verb.description: Organize or make plans for (a future event)
examples: they hoped to arrange a meeting
my aunt arranged for the furniture to be stored
we've arranged the funeral for Saturday

verb.description: Adapt (a composition) for performance with instruments or voices other than those originally specified.
examples: songs arranged for viola and piano
the quarrel, partly by the interference of the Crown Prince, was arranged

origin: Late Middle English: from Old French arangier, from a- (from Latin ad to, at) + rangier put in order (see range).
